name: Java Data Types
description: Primitive types, wrapper classes, arrays, strings, and type conversions in Java.

questions.title: Primitive Data Types
questions.description: Which of the following is NOT a primitive data type in Java?
questions.explanation: String is a reference type (class), not a primitive data type. The 8 primitive types are: byte, short, int, long, float, double, boolean, and char.

questions.title: Integer Range
questions.description: What is the range of values for the 'int' data type in Java?
questions.explanation: The int data type is a 32-bit signed integer with a range from -2^31 to 2^31-1, which is -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647.

questions.title: Byte Size
questions.description: How many bits does a 'byte' data type occupy in Java?
questions.explanation: A byte in Java is an 8-bit signed integer, ranging from -128 to 127.

questions.title: Default Values
questions.description: What is the default value of a boolean variable in Java?
questions.explanation: The default value of a boolean variable is false. All primitive types have default values when declared as instance variables.

questions.title: Character Literals
questions.description: Which of the following is a valid way to declare a char variable?
questions.explanation: A char variable must be declared with single quotes for character literals. Option 2 (char c = 65;) is also valid as it uses the ASCII value, but option 4 shows the standard character literal syntax.

questions.title: Float vs Double
questions.description: What happens when you try to compile this code?
questions.explanation: This causes a compilation error because 3.14 is treated as a double by default. You need to use 3.14f or cast it to float.

questions.title: Long Literals
questions.description: Which is the correct way to declare a long variable with value 1000000000000?
questions.explanation: Long literals must be suffixed with 'L' or 'l'. The value 1000000000000 exceeds int range, so without the L suffix, it would cause a compilation error.

questions.title: Wrapper Classes
questions.description: What is the wrapper class for the primitive type 'int'?
questions.explanation: The wrapper class for int is Integer. Each primitive type has a corresponding wrapper class: Integer, Double, Boolean, Character, etc.

questions.title: Autoboxing
questions.description: What is autoboxing in Java?
questions.explanation: Autoboxing is the automatic conversion of primitive types to their corresponding wrapper classes. In this example, the int value 5 is automatically boxed into an Integer object.

questions.title: String Immutability
questions.description: What does it mean that String objects are immutable in Java?
options: String values cannot be changed once created
questions.explanation: String immutability means that once a String object is created, its value cannot be changed. Operations like concatenation create new String objects rather than modifying existing ones.

questions.title: Array Declaration
questions.description: Which of the following is a valid array declaration in Java?
questions.explanation: All three are valid ways to declare arrays in Java. You can place brackets after the type or variable name, and initialize with new or with an initializer list.

questions.title: Array Index
questions.description: What is the index of the first element in a Java array?
questions.explanation: Java arrays are zero-indexed, meaning the first element is at index 0. In this example, numbers[0] would return 10.

questions.title: Type Casting
questions.description: What type of casting is shown in this code?
questions.explanation: This is implicit casting (also called widening conversion). Java automatically converts the int to double because no data is lost in the conversion.

questions.title: Explicit Casting
questions.description: What happens when you run this code?
questions.explanation: Explicit casting from double to int truncates the decimal part. The output will be 3, not 3.14.

questions.title: Null Values
questions.description: Which of the following can be assigned a null value?
questions.explanation: Only reference types (objects) can be assigned null values. String is a reference type, while int, boolean, and char are primitive types that cannot be null.

questions.title: Variable Initialization
questions.description: What happens when you try to use this local variable?
questions.explanation: Local variables must be initialized before use. This code will cause a compilation error because variable 'x' is not initialized.

questions.title: Final Variables
questions.description: What is true about final variables in Java?
options: They must be initialized when declared
questions.explanation: Final variables must be initialized either when declared or in the constructor, and their value cannot be changed after initialization.

questions.title: String Pool
questions.description: What is the difference between these two String declarations?
questions.code:
String s1 = "Hello";
String s2 = new String("Hello");
options: s1 uses string pool, s2 creates new object
s1 is mutable, s2 is immutable
s1 is faster, s2 is slower
questions.explanation: s1 uses the string literal pool for memory efficiency, while s2 explicitly creates a new String object in heap memory, even if 'Hello' already exists in the pool.

questions.title: Multidimensional Arrays
questions.description: How do you declare a 2D array in Java?
questions.explanation: All three syntaxes are valid for declaring 2D arrays in Java. The brackets can be placed in different positions after the type or variable name.

questions.title: Overflow Behavior
questions.description: What happens when an integer overflows in Java?
questions.explanation: Integer overflow in Java wraps around. When you exceed MAX_VALUE, it wraps to MIN_VALUE. This is called integer wraparound.

questions.title: Boolean Operations
questions.description: What is the result of this boolean expression?
questions.explanation: Due to operator precedence, && is evaluated before ||. So this becomes: (true && false) || true = false || true = true.

questions.title: Character Encoding
questions.description: What encoding does Java use for char data type?
questions.explanation: Java uses UTF-16 encoding for char data type. Each char is 16 bits and can represent Unicode characters.

questions.title: Numeric Promotion
questions.description: What is the data type of the result in this expression?
questions.explanation: In arithmetic operations, byte and short are promoted to int. The result of any arithmetic operation involving byte or short is at least an int.

questions.title: String Comparison
questions.description: What is the correct way to compare two String objects for equality?
questions.explanation: Both equals() and compareTo() == 0 correctly compare String content. The == operator compares references, not content, and may give unexpected results.

questions.title: Array Length
questions.description: How do you get the length of an array in Java?
questions.explanation: Array length is accessed using the 'length' field (not a method). Note there are no parentheses - it's a field, not a method.

questions.title: Constant Declaration
questions.description: What is the conventional way to declare a constant in Java?
questions.explanation: Constants in Java are typically declared as 'static final'. The 'static' makes it class-level, and 'final' makes it unchangeable. Java doesn't have a 'const' keyword.

questions.title: Unboxing
questions.description: What is unboxing in Java?
questions.explanation: Unboxing is the automatic conversion of wrapper class objects to their corresponding primitive types. Here, the Integer object is automatically unboxed to an int.

questions.title: Type Inference
questions.description: What feature does the 'var' keyword provide in Java 10+?
questions.explanation: The 'var' keyword provides local variable type inference. The compiler infers the type from the initializer expression. It's still statically typed.

questions.title: Primitive Wrapper Caching
questions.description: What is true about Integer caching in Java?
questions.explanation: Java caches Integer objects for values from -128 to 127. For these values, == comparison returns true because the same object is reused.

questions.title: Array Initialization
questions.description: What is the default value for elements in a newly created int array?
questions.explanation: Array elements are automatically initialized to default values. For int arrays, each element is initialized to 0. Reference type arrays are initialized to null.
